awd_titl_txt: CSBR: Living Stocks - Diversifying the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center
awd_abstract_narration:
The Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC) at The Ohio State University stores and distributes seeds, clones and other resources of Arabidopsis thaliana, a ubiquitous model system for plant research.  For the past 25 years, the ABRC has propelled cutting-edge research and discovery in photosynthesis, agricultural improvement, green technology, and basic medical research.  This award will support the ABRC's core mission to inexpensively distribute DNA and seed resources to the plant biology community, and to support plant science education by providing seeds and teaching resources free-of-charge to K-12 teachers.  This project will diversify the resources held by the ABRC into bioenergy and crop plants, aligning the ABRC with the future needs of the plant biology community.  Lastly, this project positions the ABRC to be a leader in local, national and international outreach and education, providing opportunities to inspire and train future generations of plant scientists.  

There are three specific goals of this project.  The first is to continue to provide cutting-edge resources to the global Arabidopsis community at an accessible cost.  This will be accomplished by increasing revenue through new services offered and by decreasing expenses through improved efficiency.  The ABRC also aims to increase the number of users through a second goal, which is to expand the utility of the ABRC collection by diversifying beyond Arabidopsis.  As data on other plants, including crops, are genome-enabled, they will require resource repositories.  To that end, the infrastructure of the ABRC will be leveraged to support plant biology more broadly than in the past.  The third goal is to lead local and global efforts to educate the public about plant biology.  The ABRC will also engage a broader plant science community in outreach efforts, increase awareness of plants among the general public by creating interactive activities and provide a more user-friendly online source of information for non-specialists.  These aims will function to maintain the ABRC's core mission, while strategically diversifying the organization to meet the future needs of scientists and educators worldwide.  Consult the ABRC website for further information (abrc.osu.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant funds the core mission of the Arabidopsis Biological Resource Center (ABRC) to acquire, maintain and distribute resources of the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana for use in research and education. Arabidopsis was the first plant genome to be completely sequenced and is extensively used in research and education. Many resources have been generated through collaborative research funded by NSF and other agencies and it is important to the Arabidopsis community to preserve these resources and make them widely available.

The ABRC collection contains almost 540,000 seed stocks and 450,000 non-seed stocks. Most of the seed stocks acquired during the granting period were Arabidopsis mutants that can be used to investigate gene function. Other members of the Brassica family, including mutants and wild-collected field pennycress, were also added to the collection. Of the non-seed stocks acquired during the granting period, many are resources for molecular research, including cloned Arabidopsis genes and multi-functional vectors. Resources for K-12 and college education developed by researchers and educators were also acquired, including resources suited to virtual programming. All new stocks added to the collection enter ABRC's quality control pipeline to verify germination and stock identity. Stocks reported to be incorrect, and stocks grown at ABRC are also subjected to quality control testing.

ABRC has shipped over 250,000 samples to researchers in 52 countries during the granting period. We have sent resources to 117 K-12 Educational institutions around the world. Education kits have been shipped to 44 states within the USA and to 16 other countries. Resources for K-12 education are provided free of charge. Other users of ABRC's resources pay a small fee to offset the costs of stock distribution. The payment rate in recent years has been close to 98%. The NSF contribution to our operating budget is approximately 16%, while user fees represent approximately 55% of the total budget and the remaining support is provided by The Ohio State University. Demand for stocks has been significantly impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic which impacted orders and income for 2020 and 2021.

In 2019 ABRC developed and launched a state-of-the-art database and web-based ordering tool for Arabidopsis and other plant resources. This tool allows easy access to stock data through a web interface and allows for continued collaboration and exchange of data with other Arabidopsis data providers. Google analytics data shows that the site is widely used with approximately 1,500 users per week from 62 countries. The top three countries are the United States, which represents 30% of users, China (21%), and Japan (8%). The remaining countries represent less than 5% each. We share news about ABRC's activities through the news and events section of our website and via the ABRC Twitter feed @ABRC_OSU (684 followers). Newly released stocks are listed on the researcher home page of the web site. We also attend annual meetings such as the International Conference on Arabidopsis Research (ICAR), Plant Biology, and the Science Education Council of Ohio (SECO), on a regular basis.

ABRC continues to reach out to a larger and more diverse audience through participation in community events, partnerships with community organizations and programming at local schools. ABRC reached more than 4,000 individuals per year through distribution of education resources, programs in local schools, partnerships with community organizations, teacher workshops, and on-campus outreach and engagement events. The largest audience was members of the general public reached through programming with Columbus institutions such as The Center of Science and Industry (COSI) and the Franklin Park Conservatory, and through The Ohio State University's annual West Campus Science and Technology Festival (WestFest). In response to the need for virtual teaching resources during the COVID 19 pandemic ABRC developed a paper version of our popular "Play Mendel" education kit, a self-guided 360-degree tour of the ABRC facilities, and an on-line citizen science project.

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2021
Modified by: David E Somers
